verses.text: Woe to the shepherds who destroy and scatter the sheep of my pasture, declares the Lord.
verses.comment: Here, 'shepherds' refers to Israel's rulers and spiritual leaders who failed their people. This is both literal and points ahead to the need for true, faithful leadership over God's people.

verses.text: Therefore, thus says the Lord, the God of Israel, concerning the shepherds who care for my people: You have scattered my flock and have driven them away, and you have not attended to them. Behold, I will attend to you for your evil deeds, declares the Lord.
verses.comment: God holds leaders accountable when they neglect their spiritual duties. This theme underlines the importance of divinely appointed leadership for the flock (the people of God).

verses.text: Then I will gather together the remnant of my flock out of all the lands where I have driven them, and I will bring them back to their pasture, and they will be fruitful and multiply.
verses.comment: This verse points forward to God’s restoration, which has both literal fulfillment in Israel’s return and a spiritual fulfillment in the gathering of God's people into one flock under one Shepherd. John 10:16

verses.text: I will set shepherds over them who will care for them, and they will no longer fear or be dismayed, nor will any be missing, declares the Lord.
verses.comment: God’s promise of shepherds who truly care anticipates not only faithful human leaders but ultimately Christ, the Good Shepherd, and his appointed pastors.

verses.text: Behold, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when I will raise up for David a righteous Branch, and he will reign as king and act wisely, and will do justice and righteousness in the land.
verses.comment: The 'righteous Branch' foretells the coming Messiah, Jesus, who will fulfill the Davidic line and rule with wisdom and justice—points clearly to Christ’s kingship (cf. Luke 1:32).

verses.text: In his days Judah will be saved, and Israel will dwell securely; and this is the name by which he will be called: 'The Lord is our righteousness.'
verses.comment: Christ alone is called 'The Lord our righteousness,' meaning salvation comes through him, and in him we become righteous before God. Imputed righteousness—the core of the Gospel—begins to appear here.

verses.text: Therefore, the days are coming, declares the Lord, when they will no longer say, 'As the Lord lives, who brought up the people of Israel out of the land of Egypt,'
verses.comment: A greater deliverance is foretold, overshadowing the Exodus—prophetic of Christ’s salvation that draws out people from spiritual bondage.

verses.text: but, 'As the Lord lives, who brought up and led the offspring of the house of Israel out of the north country and out of all the countries where he had driven them.' Then they will dwell in their own land.
verses.comment: God's plan is both to restore literal Israel and, in the new covenant, to gather his people into a new homeland—the Church, anticipating a spiritual 'dwelling together.'

verses.text: Concerning the prophets: My heart is broken within me, all my bones tremble; I am like a drunken man, like a man overcome by wine, because of the Lord and because of his holy words.
verses.comment: Jeremiah is overwhelmed by the burden of false prophets and the weight of God's judgment. Speaking for God is serious and fearful.

verses.text: For the land is full of adulterers; because of the curse the land mourns, and the pastures of the wilderness are dried up. Their course is evil, and their might is not right.
verses.comment: Adultery here refers both to literal immorality and spiritual unfaithfulness. Sin among leaders pollutes the land, bringing curses—a cause for repentance and renewal.

verses.text: For both prophet and priest are ungodly; even in my house I have found their evil, declares the Lord.
verses.comment: This is a serious indictment—corruption even among priests. God’s people need holy mediators to stand in the gap.

verses.text: Therefore their way will be to them like slippery paths in the darkness; they will be driven and fall into them. For I will bring disaster upon them in the year of their punishment, declares the Lord.
verses.comment: Those who sow corruption among God’s people face divine judgment. Darkness and destruction are symbols of separation from God’s blessing.

verses.text: Among the prophets of Samaria I saw an unsavory thing: They prophesied by Baal and led my people Israel astray.
verses.comment: The reference to Samaria recalls earlier apostasies in Israel. False prophecies come from following other gods, not the true God.

verses.text: But among the prophets of Jerusalem I have seen a horrible thing: they commit adultery and walk in lies. They encourage the evildoers, so that no one turns from his wickedness. All of them have become like Sodom to me, and its inhabitants like Gomorrah.
verses.comment: God’s strong condemnation signals divine displeasure. Sodom and Gomorrah represent judgment on unrepentant wickedness, warning Christian communities against tolerating immorality.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the Lord of hosts concerning the prophets: 'Behold, I will feed them with bitter food and give them poisoned water to drink, for from the prophets of Jerusalem ungodliness has gone out into all the land.'
verses.comment: False prophets not only deceive themselves but also poison the people spiritually—misleading the community away from God’s truth.

verses.text: Thus says the Lord of hosts: 'Do not listen to the words of the prophets who prophesy to you, filling you with vain hopes. They speak visions of their own minds, not from the mouth of the Lord.'
verses.comment: Discerning true teaching from false is a constant call for God’s people, who are expected to remain faithful to the authentic word of God.

verses.text: They keep saying to those who despise the word of the Lord, 'It will be well with you'; and to everyone who stubbornly follows his own heart, they say, 'No disaster will come upon you.'
verses.comment: Fake assurances comfort people in sin, rather than calling them to repentance and communion with God. Authentic ministry involves preaching uncomfortable truths when necessary.

verses.text: For who among them has stood in the council of the Lord to see and hear his word? Who has paid attention to his word and listened?
verses.comment: ‘Council of the Lord’ hints at the divine assembly and echoes the authority of God’s freely chosen messengers—true prophets must be sent.

verses.text: Behold, the storm of the Lord! Wrath has gone forth, a whirling tempest; it will burst upon the head of the wicked.
verses.comment: God’s wrath is not capricious but just—wickedness brings inevitable punishment for those who reject his law.

verses.text: The anger of the Lord will not turn back until he has executed and accomplished the purposes of his heart. In the latter days you will understand it clearly.
verses.comment: Prophecy points to final fulfillment in the 'latter days.' God’s plans are mysterious but will be revealed completely in the end.

verses.text: I did not send the prophets, yet they ran; I did not speak to them, yet they prophesied.
verses.comment: Authenticity of God’s messengers is established by divine appointment and fruit. Unauthorized prophecy is condemned.

verses.text: But if they had stood in my council, they would have made my people hear my words and would have turned them from their evil ways and from the evil of their deeds.
verses.comment: True messengers call to repentance and holiness—not mere comfort, but clear authentic proclamation with authority.

verses.text: Am I a God at hand, declares the Lord, and not a God far away?
verses.comment: God is both near and transcendent—no escape from his presence.

verses.text: Can a man hide himself in secret places so that I cannot see him? declares the Lord. Do I not fill heaven and earth? declares the Lord.
verses.comment: The omnipresence of God is asserted—a core, universal Christian doctrine about God’s nature.

verses.text: I have heard what the prophets have said who prophesy lies in my name, saying, 'I have dreamed, I have dreamed!'
verses.comment: Visions or dreams must align with revealed truth and authentic tradition, else they are false.

verses.text: How long will there be lies in the heart of the prophets who prophesy lies, and the prophets who prophesy the deceit of their own heart,
verses.comment: Lies and deceit, springing from one’s heart not from God, show the corrupt source of false prophecy.

verses.text: who think to make my people forget my name by their dreams that they tell one another, just as their fathers forgot my name for Baal?
verses.comment: The dangers of false prophecy include leading people into spiritual forgetfulness and idolatry.

verses.text: Let the prophet who has a dream tell the dream, but let him who has my word speak my word faithfully. What has straw in common with wheat? declares the Lord.
verses.comment: God’s authentic word is spiritual nourishment; all else is empty—points to the necessity of holding fast to the fullness of revealed doctrine.

verses.text: Is not my word like fire, declares the Lord, and like a hammer that breaks the rock in pieces?
verses.comment: God’s word powerfully convicts and transforms. This verse is used as a motif for the power of authoritative teaching within the Christian community.

verses.text: Therefore, behold, I am against the prophets, declares the Lord, who steal my words from one another.
verses.comment: Those who spread man-made traditions in the name of God are condemned—points to the need for safeguarding the true deposit of faith.

verses.text: Behold, I am against the prophets, declares the Lord, who use their tongues and say, 'Declares the Lord.'
verses.comment: False claims to divine authority undermine the truth, stressing the importance of spiritual discernment and fidelity to the apostolic tradition.

verses.text: Behold, I am against those who prophesy lying dreams, declares the Lord, and who tell them and lead my people astray by their lies and their recklessness, when I did not send them or command them. So they do not profit this people at all, declares the Lord.
verses.comment: Prophecies not divinely authorized lead God’s people away. Authentic officeholders act only with divine commission.

verses.text: When one of this people or a prophet or a priest asks you, 'What is the burden of the Lord?' you shall say to them, 'You are the burden, and I will cast you off, declares the Lord.'
verses.comment: God will reject those who persist in disrespect and self-deceit—even the leaders are held accountable.

verses.text: And as for the prophet, priest, or anyone from the people who says, 'The burden of the Lord,' I will punish that man and his household.
verses.comment: Misusing spiritual language and office for self-promotion brings God’s judgment.

verses.text: Thus you shall say, every one to his neighbor and every one to his brother, 'What has the Lord answered?' or 'What has the Lord spoken?'
verses.comment: True spiritual inquiry should focus on authentic revelation, not curiosity or superstition.

verses.text: But the burden of the Lord you shall mention no more, for every man's word is his own burden, and you pervert the words of the living God, the Lord of hosts, our God.
verses.comment: Corruption of God’s word is condemned; tampering with or adding to God’s revelation leads to judgment.

verses.text: Thus you shall say to the prophet, 'What has the Lord answered you?' or 'What has the Lord spoken?'
verses.comment: The need for humility and reverence in seeking God’s will is assumed all throughout authoritative communities.

verses.text: But if you say, 'The burden of the Lord,' thus says the Lord, 'Because you have said these words,
verses.comment: Reiterates that using supposed divine messages to manipulate or elevate oneself brings God’s strong rebuke. Only authentic authority is to be trusted.

verses.text: therefore, behold, I will surely lift you up and cast you away from my presence, you and the city that I gave to you and your fathers.
verses.comment: God withdrawing his presence signals the ultimate consequence for rejecting true authority and revelation.

verses.text: And I will bring upon you everlasting reproach and perpetual shame, which shall not be forgotten.
verses.comment: Final judgment is real and eternal for those who corrupt God’s people or abuse leadership, reminding all to cling to truth and the divinely-constituted order of faith.
